author: roundelephant
content:
I think we're using two different definitions of "trustless". To me, trustless staking is enabled as soon as  smart contracts can be set as the withdrawal address -- I consider <@!291925846556540928>'s proposal to enable "trustless" staking since no one  needs to custody the withdrawal key (this is what pools like RocketPool are waiting for). 

I think you have a higher standard of "trustless" than this, right? Your proposal goes further in that it is concerned with distributing the validator keys themselves, right?

author: djrtwo
content:
Hey, so I would like to release the 0x01 credentials very soon, but I want to better understand if the fact that the contract can't trigger exits is a major issue for this first round of credentails
(yes, maybe post merge there can be an operation type that is triggered from eth1 contract layer to the consensus to mitigate this issue but would be a different credential -- maybe a 0x02 or something)

author: djrtwo
content: So essentially with 0x01 as specified, an eth1 contract can custody the funds once a validator exits but the contract has no recourse or control over a rogue operator

author: djrtwo
content: there are unfortunate things that can come into play if the operator doesn't exit. you could imagine holding the funds hostage or something

author: djrtwo
content: I don't know the staking pool designs well enough to know if the 0x01 credentials are *good enough* for today

author: djrtwo
content: so am seeking some more explicit input around this issue

author: dapplion

author: roundelephant
content:
I'm only versed on RocketPool. But, your proposal seems like it would be good enough for their purposes.

RocketPool validator operators must put up 16 ETH themselves and the other half is from the pool. So they wouldn't be able to hold the funds hostage without holding an equal amount of their own ETH hostage -- their protocol has an economic deterrent to this hostage scenario.
